text:
Sands Street, at the N.E. corner of Fulton Street. The trolley tracks are on Fulton Street. It is a view of Brook's Furniture Store. In 1880 the building was in existence but shortly thereafter it was demolished to make way for the Fulton Street Elevated Lines, and a further approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

About 1882.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1).  Brooklyn Bridge (suspension); beginning at Centre Street and Park Row, facing City Hall Park, in Manhattan, and terminating in Brooklyn at Fulton and Sands Streets. Actual work was begun in January, 1870 and it was completed in May, 1884, having been opened in the previous year. Its overall length is 1 1/4 miles, width 85 feet, with a central span across the East River, 1595 feet long and 135 feet above high water mark. John A. Roebling, who drew up the specifications and began construction was succeeded upon his death by his son, Washington A. Roebling. Being the first bridge to connect Manhattan and Brooklyn, it acquired a colorful history and world-wide fame as a wonder of modern engineering and human endeavor. (see: Moses King, Handbook of New York City (1892).)

June 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(2). Same
June 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(3). Same
June 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
